top_comment.text:
I still dont get why people still pay for retro games in the ps2 and older 
era. Pretty much most of the cartridge based games are playable on each 
ancient computers. So one could easily play gb, gbc, gba, nes, snes, sega 
genesis, etc. Plus the games are all available in digital roms ready for 
play. So you have access to the complete collection and you dont have to 
worry about whether a game is good or not as the game is free.﻿
top_comment.author: Asad the great

comments.text:
+Asad the great When I was dead broke I was all about roms/ISO's, but once 
I got a job I wanted to actually own the games I had played so much for 
free. Because of a lack of space, I switched to running roms from my Wii's 
SD drive. I think that's the best way to play classic games, since the Wii 
offers so many controller options and runs most roms for the NES/Sega/Snes 
with no problems. It also let's you play those old pixelated games on a 
modern tv with no blurring.

Of course, that's for "classic" games. Games from the PSX era on you should 
really just own. Most are pretty cheap (except for games like Tomba, IQ., 
etc.) and are much more fun and creative than the crap you have on Xbone or 
PS4
comments.author: jesus duran

comments.text:
+NINJAASSASSINGAMERZ
right on most pc controllers work with emulators.
comments.author: Asad the great

comments.text:
Just buy the controller and an adapter for it to PC. Basically the same 
thing... Maybe even faster.
comments.author: NINJAASSASSINGAMERZ

comments.text:
+Vernon Schaal
well as far as real controller is concerned, you can use most pc 
controllers with emulators. and most if not all pcs can be used with hdtvs 
to create a couch play experience
comments.author: Asad the great

comments.text:
its not the same as owning it, and sitting on your couch, with the real 
controller is much better then any emulation.
comments.author: Vernon Schaal

comments.text:
+Asad the great
drm can be bypassed, but generally speaking ya something like that. (I 
honestly haven'tt use itunes or my ipod in the past few years)

I wasn't preaching I love itunes or anything, but pointing out some of the 
positives to the consumer.

But as you say, there are downsides.
comments.author: TheJadeFist

comments.text:
+TheJadeFist one thing, arnt songs downloaded from itune not able to be 
transferred to non-ios devices like android or windows smartphones. Meaning 
if you change from an iphone to another non-ios device, you could 
potentially lose all your music.
comments.author: Asad the great

comments.text:
+katakisLives
Partially, but remember when  Itunes came out it still had to compete with 
those services, and yet by offering a cheap and easy way to get songs 
people wanted, they were perfectly happy to pay for it. Plus and this is a 
big one, when you download a song from itunes you're not gonna get some 
crazy Russian virus.

Buying them through these services offered that added level of security, 
even if the itunes client itself is a bit invasive and resource hungry.
comments.author: TheJadeFist

comments.text:
+katakisLives well I am still in strong support of piracy as far as movies 
and music go. $20 a movie and $10-15 for 12 songs is too much. Steam sale 
prices has encouraged me to buy pc games.
comments.author: Asad the great

comments.text:
+TheJadeFist I still buy all my music on CD because I like to have 
something physical to show for my monetary outlay! I'd also suggest maybe 
part of the decline in piracy is down to a lot of the classic peer to peer 
download services like kazaar and llimewire being shut down and the rise of 
streaming
comments.author: katakisLives

comments.text:
+ValanceJ I do a little bit of both! I own hundreds of games and they are 
stacked high and its not always easy to find a particular game so I will 
play the rom version sometimes! plus with disk format games like on the 
Amiga a lot of them have demagnetized over the years and no longer work so 
I have to play the emulation!
comments.author: katakisLives

comments.text:
+VicGeorge2K6 Ideally I would agree! but sometimes the hardware is not all 
that reliable! I've got three Nintendo entertainment systems and they all 
suffer from the flashing red light of death problem! I do both because it 
can also be quite a hassle getting the old systems out too
comments.author: katakisLives

comments.text:
+Asad the great
What if I told you most of those console games can be ill gotten on the 
pirate bay for pc?

Yet Steam is doing quite well for itself these days. Granted I only buy 
things on sale, because I'm a cheap skate, I still rather buy it then 
pirate it. Plus I don't see the value in paying 50-60 bucks for a digital 
copy, I would however be willing to spend that on new release physical copy 
of something.

I'm not judging you, i'm simply trying to illustrate the thinking behind 
the decision to buy something when it can be gotten for free through other 
means.

Like my gum analogy above, Why steal a game you can buy for 5 bucks?

Some part of you probably still finds value in those console games, and 
deams them worth your money.

I know people who will watch movies for free online, but still go out and 
buy most of the major releases when they come to dvd/ blueray. Or will 
happily go to the theatre.

I guess the feeling of ownership comes into play as well, as was stated by 
ValanceJ up there.

There are plenty of reasons someone might want to buy it.
comments.author: TheJadeFist

comments.text:
except console games, I havnt paid for any other form of media in the last 
decade or so. My justification is that movies and music in retail stores 
are an overpriced affair. $20 for a movie is out there pricing for me.
comments.author: Asad the great

comments.text:
Why is Itunes successful in a world where any idiot can find and listen to 
any song they want to for free?

There is also part of it to support the content creators, but there is also 
the format of delivery.

Over 90% of piracy is due to lack of proper distribution, alot of people 
would actually rather not steal something when its cheaply available. Its 
like stealing a 50 cent pack of gum just makes you a dick.

I can see justifying piracy to something that you already own, or is no 
longer available for sale by the publisher. Also if is other wise 
inconvenient due to DRM, or exorbitantly over-priced (that becomes a 
protest, and is sometimes justified to demonstrate to the publishers that 
their product is wanted and to not quit making it, but people aren't 
willing to put up with the BS attached to it).

I suppose it really comes down to, are you willing to show your financial 
support for the games? Is that worth your money to you?
comments.author: TheJadeFist

comments.text:
Because playing old games isn't always just about playing the game. You 
collect physical copies of games or whatever you collect to be surrounded 
by things that you enjoy.
comments.author: ValanceJ

comments.text: +bigguyjames34 How about retro hardware with a flashcart, then?
comments.author: Code7ULC

comments.text:
Because it brings back a nostalgic feeling that you don't get with a 
computer.
comments.author: bigguyjames34

comments.text:
+VicGeorge2K6
I suppose but the difference is like paying for something that can be had 
for free.
comments.author: Asad the great

comments.text:
Because there are people who feel it is better to just play the old games 
on authentic ancient hardware rather than emulated on a modern computer.
comments.author: VicGeorge2K6

top_comment.text: Still waiting on super nes remix. That will be the wii u seller.﻿

captions.text:
You could say a lot about this game before
you ever pick up a controller. You could say

it’s another rehash. Another example of
Nintendo milking the past instead of looking

to the future. You could say it’s just a
collection of old games you’ve played a

hundred times before, even purchased a hundred
times before. And you know something?
You’d be right. You’d be absolutely right.

But after that, if you did pick up the controller,
you wouldn’t put it down. You’d be stuck

in the past, too. As glued to your television
now as you were in 1986. These games…they

have this intangible magic that never fades,
that never gets old…that never stops being
fun.
You could say a lot about NES Remix.

But more than anything else, it never stops
being fun.

At first glance, playing NES Remix would seem
like going through an old yearbook. It’s

just a flood of memories. So vivid, you can
almost see your childhood passing by. In pixels.

But if you think that’s all this is? Just
another nostalgia trip? Take another look.

This game is obviously a celebration of the
past, but…it’s not just…like, a picture
of your old girlfriend.

It’s meeting up with her, and finding out
she has a new haircut, she lost the glasses…and

she stopped doing that annoying thing, where
you had to blow on her pin connectors.

So NES Remix is all about its characters.
Most of them are, like, 30 years old. There’s

Mario, Donkey Kong, Link, the whole crew.
But there’s also a character working behind

the scenes, so to speak. A slightly younger
character…who, likes to fart. See, NES Remix

is basically just the NES version of WarioWare.
Had that game come out in 1989?
This is what it would’ve looked like.

NES Remix takes the games that defined a generation…and
deconstructs them. What you’re left with…are

microgames. Tiny pieces of gaming excellence,
only rearranged and completely out of context.

It kind of makes no sense, but…it also makes
perfect sense.

So there are 16 NES games sampled here. You
get the obvious heavy hitters, as well as

a couple surprises. Urban Champion, I’m
looking at you. And each of those games has

their own set of microgames. They start easy
enough…the first Zelda game just has you

picking up your sword. But it’s not long
before that changes. You’re never doing

anything that isn’t a simple action from
that game…but NES Remix has you doing them
in crazy new ways.

Get to the goalpost in Mario…but with the
level as a silhouette.

Jump over Donkey Kong’s barrels…when you
can’t see them coming.

What’s so brilliant about NES Remix…is
that it takes the most familiar moments in

gaming history, and makes them unfamiliar.
That plays on your expectations in really
clever ways.

In total, there are more than 200 of these
challenges…and it’s actually bigger than

it sounds, as some of the microgames actually
have several parts. So they might jump from

Excitebike to Ice Climber and Clu Clu Land…within
the same microgame, which is awesome. The

game totally has that frantic, fast-paced
feel that defines the WarioWare games.

In fact, this is a better WarioWare game than
Game and Wario. And again, half the fun comes

from the ridiculousness of it all. You get
to save Mario from Donkey Kong…as Luigi.

You get to save Pauline…as Link. Who, by
the way, still can’t jump.
So good luck with those barrels.

Now, on the negative side…no multiplayer.
Which really seems like a missed opportunity.

The hectic gameplay, combined with the nostalgia
and the clever design…it seems you could

really do some cool things with multiplayer
here. Unfortunately, NES Remix doesn’t.

But on the plus side, it does support off-screen
play, which is awesome. So is the music.
And there’s a lot of stuff, too.

Each level has three possible stars, so you’re
always pushing yourself to get that perfect

score…and there’s a ton of collectible
8-bit stamps, which you can use in the Miiverse.

But you know, all the complaints you could
make about this game…they really do go away

as soon as you pick up the controller. It’s
kind of amazing, actually. How games this

old can still be this great. And it’s a
testament to how strong their design is…that

you can break them down, and build them up
into these crazy gaming Frankensteins…and
they’re still great.

Yeah, it sucks that Metroid and Kid Icarus
aren’t here.
And sure, multiplayer would’ve been nice.

But they can fix that in NES Remix 2. And
then follow that with Super NES Remix, and

then Nintendo 64 remix. And yeah, we’ll
complain about rehashes. But then we’ll

blow up Bowser with a morph bomb. And our
only complaint will be that there’s no NES
Remix 3.

I don’t mind revisiting the past. Not when
the past has never been better.

title: CGR Undertow - NES REMIX review for Nintendo Wii U
